The valet guys were super nice, and when we got inside the guy at the front desk was also incredibly sympathetic and would have upgraded us to a better room had there been any available. When he was telling us about the wine hour hosted in the lobby every afternoon, we sighed and said we should have been there for that if it hadn't been for our delays. And so he went and fetched us a bottle from the back, handed it to us and hoped that our weekend would only get better from here on out. That evening we had dinner at JSix restaurant (attached to the hotel). The food, service and wine were all very good and the staff incredibly attentive and friendly. We had to pay $18 a night parking fees - which is I suppose par for the course for any downtown hotel these days. Other than that, I had no complaints at all about our service, and considering the price I paid for the room, was all in all extremely impressed. And the decor is beautiful. Sometimes the beauty doesn't quite work as functionally as one might like (e.g. the lovely looking sinks in which it's virtually impossible to wash!) The locationis fantastic (Gaslamp quarter) and SD is a clean, neat, friendly and accessible city. We also ate dinner at Buon Appetito in Little Italy (took the city tramline to get there, incredibly easy). Brunch on Sunday at Hash House A Go Go in Hillcrest (don't eat for 24 hours before you go, or SHARE), and dinner Sunday night at George's by the Cove Terrace in La Jolla. Would recommend all of them.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Hotel, but that's all it has to offer.”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: After reading some other comments regarding the Hotel Solamar, I see that in most instances I was not alone. My husband and I thought we just had terrible luck, but it's obvious that this hotel still has a lot of work to do. The hotel its self is beautiful, but they seriously need more training in guest service. Upon my arrival the valet didn't help me with my luggage nor was there a bell person. At the front desk, first they couldn't find my reservation and then the girl checking me in handed me off to someone else because she was trying to check me in and do something else at the same time. Finally, after I was checked in I was not offered to have my bags brought to my room, I had to take them up myself. I read in another review that because it was his/her birthday they got a room upgrade and champagne, not so for me. Not even a "happy birthday." My husband and I ordered room service for some appetizers prior to hitting the town and were told it would be twenty minutes. Well, it never came! After going out that night we were hungry when we got back to the hotel, but it was too late to eat at there restaurant and the late night room service menu only had 3 items. We called the concierge for recommendations for late night dining and he referred us to a place that he said was open and served dinner until 1pm. When we arrived, approximatley 11:45pm, they were closing and had stopped serving dinner at 10pm. I was furious but found a place that was open and served dinner. There were little things that happened that just added up and I was not at all pleased with the service we received from this hotel's staff. I've stayed at many other hotels ranked higher and lower than Hotel Solamar and can promise that I did not receive even close to the level of service at these other hotels. I expected superior service or better from a hotel like Solamar and I was extremely disappointing especially given the amount of money you pay per night. At the end of our stay I made sure to check out at the front desk and tell them my experience, and that too was a disappointing response. I didn't want anything, per say, but I heart felt "I'm sorry" and ask for details would have been somewhat decent of them. I felt like the girl who checked me out did not care and was told by soemone else who over heard my conversation with her that they would have the General Manager contact me. A week later, no reponse. So I emailed the hotel and got a call from the Asst. GM and he was very kind and attentive. He even offered a free night to make it up to me and my husband and so we can "experience the Hotel Solamar the way it really should be experienced." He took down my address and to no surprise...over two months have gone by since that conversationa and we never received anything from him in the mail! With that said, we have no itentions of ever returning, nor refer any friends, family and especially our clients (we're local corporate business owners) to this hotel. I'd much rather pay more money and stay at a hotel, like the Omni which is not far from there, and receive far better service.

Reviews.Title: “Going to a Padres game?”
Reviews.Author: PKCinLA
Reviews.Content: If you are in town for a Padres game, the Solamar is a great option. The stadium is a block away...it's also close to 5th street in the Gaslamp. Has a modern, hip, boutique vibe reminiscent of the W chain. Nice, clean room on the 10th floor overlooking the pool/bar. Decor is trendy. Bed was great, comfortable chair, great shower. Sinks were stylish but not very functional. Service was low key. Shouldn't be an issue unless you are high maintenance. Valet parking was convenient and efficient. The pool/bar scene seemed lively but a bit touristy. They have a complimentary wine happy hour, but the wine is low grade. Get a head start on your night instead. Very good experience overall. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Gorgeous!”
Reviews.Author: gretchenenders
Reviews.Content: I too went to the Solamar for a weekend getaway and we couldn't have had a more relaxing, wonderful time. The hotel is gorgeous! From the rich dark woods of the lobby to the large, funky guest rooms. Every detail was well thought out by the designers and comes together beautifully. The sun broke just as we arrived in San Diego so we were able to take full advantage of the rooftop bar/pool. You couldn't ask for a more picturesque setting. Although there wasn't a Padres game being played at the time, you could almost feel the summertime energy emitting from the baseball field across the street. You must take advantage of the wine hour as it provides for great people watching and allows you a chance to spend some time in the beautiful lobby, rather than just walking through it while coming and going. The main drag for restaurants and bars is just a block away which was a wonderful perk. All of the staff was warm and welcoming, from the moment we checked in to having beers on the pool deck, everyone was incredibly helpful and inviting. I can't wait to go back and I will highly recommend to anyone, regarless of your length of stay!

Reviews.Title: “Solamar, take me away”
Reviews.Author: Elyse1316
Reviews.Content: After a hectic week at work, my boyfriend and I needed a quick get away. We "Pricelined" a 4-star hotel in San Diego and were extactic to come back with the Solamar. I had read some positive and some negative reviews, but i wanted to check it out for myself. I think some travelers must expect their lives to go on without a hitch and no one makes mistakes, which is what I was gathering from some other reviews. However, my experience was top notch. The front desk staff was extremely friendly and polite. We entered our room and I was pleased with the clean, soothing color palate and decor. The bed was very comfortable and the bathroom a nice size. We met a local friend at the pool for a few drinks and snacks. The drink menu is creative and delicious as well as the bar appetizer menu. The seating area at the pool has something for everyone, whether it be lounging poolside or having conversation under the canopy. We then joined our fellow guests at the wine hour and enjoyed a couple glasses of wine before getting ready for dinner. We returned from dinner out in the Gaslamp and wanted to join the hip crowd at the pool, but couldn't muster up the energy. Our room overlooked the pool bar and we scoped out the scene for a little while. Overall, I would highly recommend Hotel Solmar.

Reviews.Title: “A Place to Stay but don't Overpay”
Reviews.Author: cineart
Reviews.Content: I don't know what's up with San Diego but it seems that all the hotels in the gaslamp area are charging New York prices. The convention center is very busy with New Orleans convention overflow and any decent place within walking distance of gaslamp is charging about $300/night plus $22 parking. I decided to play Russian roulette with Hotwire and bid a four star gaslamp area hotel for $204/night +taxes (for a Thursday and Friday night stay) I got the Solamar, a new boutique hotel that bills itself as four stars. Iâ€™ve read the other reviews here and thought Iâ€™d add some comments. The staff was all top notch and I encountered no rude or sub par service as mentioned before. The lobby is well appointed and a nice place to relax and the 4th floor bar is also a nice hangout. The workout room is a joke- the smallest Iâ€™ve ever seen with about four pieces of equipment. The pool is also a ridiculous 3â€™ deep and therefore useless. The hotel is new so the rooms and furnishings are clean. But here is the real point of my review â€“value. Our room was very, very small â€“so small that it didnâ€™t have the requisite â€˜two chairs and a table by the window set-upâ€™ in case you wanted to invite a guest up to your room. More importantly, the rooms were poorly insulated. Any seasoned traveler knows the awful sound of heavy fireproof hotel doors slamming early in the morning as Business Bob leaves at 6:30AM for a meeting. We could hear next-door conversations and the maid vacuuming at 8:00AM very clearly. All of this does not fit in my definition of a four star hotel. Yes the room was decorated in a funky hip style. But with the room size and noise it felt like the Solamar built regular, small and acoustically sub par rooms and then hired a decorator to do an â€˜extreme makeoverâ€™ adding drapes, some funky lamps and art. That just doesnâ€™t cut it for their regular $300/night rates. At $204 I felt neither screwed nor did I feel I got any value. If I paid just $5 more a night I might have been pissed. The lobby and bar may look four star but after all I am paying for a room. Iâ€™d stay here again but if I had to pay $300 Iâ€™d choose the Marriot Gas lamp (NOT the other Marriot monster convention hotel by the water!!) The Marriot Gas lamp may not have a basin type Kohler sink and funky drapes but the standard rooms are big, immaculate, and have an equally unique California Craftsman style about it. Hope this helps!

HotelInfo.Name: Hotel Solamar - a Kimpton Hotel
